items.title: Farm lobbyist: Ag leaders need to rethink safety net
items.description: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. ‚Äì Farmers have become so dependent on disaster payments in recent years that agricultural leaders need to rethink the farm safety net, a prominent crop insurance lobbyist said during the Crop Insurance...
items.summary:
Key Points:

1. Farm lobbyist Tara Smith, executive vice president of the Torrey Advisory Group, says agricultural leaders need to rethink the farm safety net.

2. Since 2018, the U.S. has spent $14 billion per year on ad hoc disaster payments, more than the combined spending on Title 1 programs and crop insurance.

3. Smith states that this high level of ad hoc disaster spending indicates flaws in the underlying farm policy.

4. While the crop insurance program has expanded to better meet the needs of farmers, Smith says it is not the only piece of the safety net that needs to be considered.

5. The higher reference prices and other spending in the One Big Beautiful Bill Act will help, but Smith says agricultural leaders should always think about the future of farm policy, especially given the high current spending levels.

6. Smith emphasizes that "defensibility plus effectiveness equals longevity" when it comes to farm policy.

7. Economist Eden Lambert of the Torrey Advisory Group says there are underlying market issues that need to be addressed in the farm economy.

8. Smith notes that if Congress does not complete a new farm bill, farm policy would be solely in the hands of the administration, which could lead to significant swings from one administration to the next.

items.title: Commerce investigates dumping of winter strawberries
items.description: The Commerce Department has announced the initiation of an antidumping duty investigation of fresh winter strawberries from Mexico.The petitioners are Florida strawberry groups. ‚ÄìThe Hagstrom Report
items.summary:
Key points:

- The U.S. Commerce Department has initiated an antidumping duty investigation on fresh winter strawberries imported from Mexico.
- The petitioners are Florida strawberry groups who allege that Mexican strawberry producers are "dumping" their products in the U.S. market at unfairly low prices.
- The investigation will determine if Mexican strawberry imports are being sold in the U.S. at less than fair value, causing injury to the domestic Florida strawberry industry.
- No specific dumping margin or timeline for the investigation has been provided yet.
- This follows similar trade disputes between the U.S. and Mexico over seasonal produce like tomatoes and bell peppers.
- The outcome could lead to the imposition of antidumping duties on Mexican strawberry imports if they are found to be dumped.
- This would impact U.S. consumers who rely on affordable Mexican strawberries during the winter months when domestic production is lower.

items.title: Allison: Private lands matter in protecting wildlife
items.description: In New Mexico, when people think about wildlife and nature, they often envision public lands. Our national forests and rangelands, monuments, wildlife refuges and state trust lands are important both to wildlife and to people....
items.summary:
5 million out of their own pockets for conservation efforts - an amount comparable to major federal conservation funding sources. This includes restoring streams, removing invasive species, improving soils, maintaining water infrastructure, and managing land through drought, fire, and flood. However, in the same year, these landowners also absorbed an estimated $101 million in uncompensated losses from wildlife damage to fences, forage, and crops, with only a small fraction receiving any compensation. 

Private and working lands in New Mexico, which make up over half the state's land, provide essential habitat for most of the state's wildlife, including migratory big game and threatened/endangered species. They also support the rural economy and culture by producing food/fiber, sustaining livelihoods, and contributing to county tax bases. However, the high costs of this land stewardship make it unsustainable, leading to land being converted to other uses and the loss of vital wildlife habitat.

Lesli Allison, CEO of the Western Landowners Alliance, states that partnerships, policies, and economic opportunities are needed to recognize and leverage the investments landowners make to sustain wildlife, communities, and the open West. Private lands play a critical role that is often overlooked compared to public lands in wildlife and natural resource protection.

items.title: February 17 Wildfires kill livestock, injure responders
items.description: Feb. 17 wildfires kill livestock, injure responders Wildfires ripped across areas of Oklahoma, Kansas, Texas and Nebraska, killing livestock, destroying structures and sending firefighters to the hospital with fire and smoke related injuries. Winds gusting...
items.summary:
The largest fire, the Ranger Road fire in Beaver County, Oklahoma, burned over 283,000 acres and forced evacuations in the towns of Ashland and Englewood, Kansas. 

The article provides the following key details:

- The Ranger Road fire was started by unknown causes and crossed into Kansas, destroying structures and killing cows. A rancher lost around 200 cows, while another was able to save his hay yard and feed truck by backfiring.

- The National Interagency Fire Center indicates an "above normal" significant wildfire potential in Kansas, Texas, Oklahoma, Colorado, and Wyoming, fueled by "abnormally dry" to "extreme drought" conditions across the region.

- A Red Flag Warning is in effect in parts of Texas, Oklahoma, Kansas, New Mexico, and Colorado due to continued dry, windy conditions and low humidity.

- Three firefighters were injured when their fire truck overturned while navigating a smoke-filled pasture during the Ranger Road fire. The driver was trapped and two were ejected, all suffering serious injuries.

The article highlights the devastating impact these February 17 wildfires have had on livestock and first responders in the affected states, driven by dangerous drought and weather conditions in the region.

items.title: Schuler Red Angus honored for commitment to community and education
items.description: Input, leadership, and education were all words used to describe the collaborative efforts of Schuler Red Angus when owners Butch and David Schuler received the 2025 Outstanding Service to Agriculture Award from the University of...
items.summary:
Schuler Red Angus honored for commitment to community and education

- Schuler Red Angus owners Butch and David Schuler received the 2025 Outstanding Service to Agriculture Award from the University of Nebraska Panhandle Research, Extension and Education Center (PREEC).
- The award was presented by Dr. John Westra, PREEC Director, at the annual Beef Feedlot Roundtables on February 17, 2025, in Bridgeport, Nebraska.
- PREEC faculty gives this award annually to a business, organization, or individual who has enhanced the university's mission of research, teaching, and extension outreach.
- Schuler Red Angus was recognized for their leadership, service, and dedication to agriculture in the Panhandle region, as well as their meaningful and lasting impact on the broader community.
- Over the past few years, Schuler Red Angus has provided valuable outreach opportunities, including hosting wildfire recovery meetings, cheatgrass management education, and hosting multiple UNL student groups on their ranch.
- The Schulers have provided valuable input and leadership on facilitating relevant research and extension programming at PREEC, and in 2025, they hosted a cattle management tour group from Argentina.

items.title: Purdue Virtual Series to Assist Families with Farm Succession
items.description: HUNTINGTON, Ind. ‚Äî The Purdue Extension Succession Planning Team is hosting the virtual workshop, ‚ÄúSecuring the Future: Legal Audits for Farm Families and Agricultural Success,‚Äù over the next several months. This virtual program series is offered at no cost to participants. The team has built sessions to support farm families as they prepare for legal […] The post Purdue Virtual Series to Assist Families with Farm Succession appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
This program aims to support farm families as they prepare for the legal aspects of farm business transition and succession planning.

The 8-session series will be held on March 2, March 9, June 22, June 29, July 13, August 12, August 24, and August 31 from 6:30-8pm EST (5:30-7pm CST). Presenters will include Purdue Extension Educators and Specialists, as well as Scott Linneweber, a Shareholder Attorney from Eagle & Fein, P.C.

Topics to be covered include: organizing farm and family history, difficult conversations, contingency planning, operating/buy-sell agreements, personal estate planning, planning for incapacity, management transfer, and land leases/tenant relationships. 

This work is supported by a grant from the U.S. Department of Agriculture's National Institute of Food and Agriculture, awarded to the North Central Extension Risk Management Education Center.

Farmers can register for the full 8-session program series at https://bit.ly/securingthefuture2026. The goal is to help farm families successfully navigate the legal and logistical complexities of farm business transition and succession.

items.title: Great Lakes Forage and Grazing Conference is March 19
items.description: EAST LANSING, Mich. ‚Äî The Michigan Forage Council and Michigan State University Extension are excited to announce that the 2026 Great Lakes Forage and Grazing Conference will be held Thursday, March 19. The theme for this year‚Äôs conference is ‚ÄúBack to the Basics of Making a Profit.‚Äù This event is geared toward forage producers, students, […] The post Great Lakes Forage and Grazing Conference is March 19 appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
The 2026 Great Lakes Forage and Grazing Conference will be held on Thursday, March 19 in Harrison, Michigan. The theme is "Back to the Basics of Making a Profit" and it is geared towards forage producers, students, graziers, agribusiness professionals, and educators. 

Key details:
- Location: CTE John C. Magnus Center, 3200 S Clare Ave, Harrison, MI 48625
- Registration is $65 before March 15 and $75 after
- Keynote speakers are Ben and Denise Bartlett of Log Cabin Livestock in the Upper Peninsula
- Presentation topics include 45 years of best forage practices, MSU forage research, grazing plans, preventing hay fires, and virtual fencing technology
- Organized by Michigan Forage Council and MSU Extension

The conference aims to provide hands-on knowledge, Michigan-based expertise, and practical tools for forage producers to improve profitability. Attendees will have opportunities to network with vendors and hear from experienced farmers and experts throughout the day.

items.title: In Insect Farming, Bugs ARE the System!
items.description: WASHINGTON ‚Äî You can learn a lot by watching chickens on a cold morning when the ground is frozen and the grass has stopped growing. They don‚Äôt pace the edge of the run. They hunt‚Äîscratching, pecking, flipping leaves and mulch like they‚Äôre turning pages in a book only they can read. If they find a […] The post In Insect Farming, Bugs ARE the System! appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
Black soldier fly larvae are highlighted as a nutrient-dense option, containing 35-45% crude protein and 25-35% fat, along with essential amino acids and calcium. 

Insect farming allows nutrients to cycle close to home, converting byproducts into chicken feed. Different insect species like black soldier flies, mealworms, and crickets suit varying farm conditions. Experts recommend insects as a strategic 5-15% supplement in poultry diets, especially during molting, peak lay, or environmental stress.

While on-farm insect production requires daily management, purchased insect meal can also provide the nutritional benefits. Proper temperature, moisture, and feedstock balance are critical to successful insect farming systems. Extension guidance and peer experience are recommended to navigate the learning curve.

Overall, insect farming for poultry feed reflects a commitment to biological alignment, nutrient cycling, and supply chain resilience on the farm. It offers a practical protein solution aligned with chickens' natural foraging behavior.

items.title: 2026 Priorities Discussed at OFBF‚Äôs Ag Day at the Capital
items.description: COLUMBUS, Ohio ‚Äî A large contingent of Ohio Farm Bureau members gathered at the Ohio Statehouse in Columbus Feb.18 for the organization‚Äôs annual Ag Day at the Capital, meeting one-on-one with state legislators and staff to discuss policy priorities impacting Ohio‚Äôs farms and rural communities. During the event, Ohio Farm Bureau unveiled its 2026 priority […] The post 2026 Priorities Discussed at OFBF‚Äôs Ag Day at the Capital appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Ohio Farm Bureau (OFBF) held its annual Ag Day at the Capital on February 18, 2026 in Columbus, Ohio.
- OFBF unveiled its 2026 policy priorities, including preserving Ohio's farmland, smart land use legislation, transparency in the Current Agricultural Use Value (CAUV) program, and investment in Ohio's food supply chain.
- OFBF members advocated for two specific bills - HB 575 to bring changes and uniformity to CAUV, and HB 646 to create a statewide study commission on data centers and their environmental impacts.
- Speakers at the event included OFBF leadership, as well as John Newton, Ph.D., Vice President of Public Policy and Economic Analysis at American Farm Bureau.
- OFBF's mission is to work together for Ohio farmers to advance agriculture and strengthen communities.

items.title: Bloom for Good launches ag advocacy savings app
items.description: Bloom for Good launched a savings app that supports 4-H, FFA and Ag in the Classroom through digital membership purchases. The post Bloom for Good launches ag advocacy savings app appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Bloom for Good, a mission-driven company, has launched a new Advocating for Agriculture savings app to create ongoing financial support for 4-H, FFA, and Ag in the Classroom programs nationwide. 

Key details:
- The app offers a one-year digital savings membership with discounts at businesses, with a portion of purchases going back to agricultural education organizations.
- The introductory membership price is $15 (regularly $25).
- Proceeds from membership purchases will support state and national efforts tied to 4-H, FFA, and Ag in the Classroom, helping fund curriculum, leadership development, classroom resources, and hands-on learning opportunities.
- The program aims to address challenges facing agriculture, including workforce shortages and declining agricultural literacy, by giving supporters a simple way to contribute.
- Missy Rosenbusch, Vice President of Agriculture Advocacy & Impact at Bloom for Good, said "This campaign is about more than savings - it's about advocating with an impact. Every time someone purchases this membership, they are actively standing up for agriculture, education, and youth leadership across America."

The app is intended to be a renewable, year-round campaign that makes it easy for individuals, families, and corporate partners to support the future of agriculture.

items.title: Ag economist expects cattle markets to face another year of volatility
items.description: A livestock economist says he anticipates another volatile year in the cattle markets. Derrell Peel with Oklahoma State University says the futures market will likely overreact when the U.S. resumes importing live cattle from Mexico. ‚ÄúThe futures market will react negatively, at least for a couple of days,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúBut then I think we’re going to figure out that it’s a […] The post Ag economist expects cattle markets to face another year of
items.summary:
The key points from the article are:

- Livestock economist Derrell Peel from Oklahoma State University expects another volatile year in the cattle markets in 2023.

- He anticipates the futures market will likely overreact when the U.S. resumes importing live cattle from Mexico. Peel says the market will initially react negatively for a couple of days, but then will realize it's a relatively small volume of cattle.

- Peel expects overall cattle supplies to be down in 2023 compared to 2022, with reduced calf crops and fewer cattle being placed in feedlots. This could lead to continued volatility and higher prices for cattle.

- However, Peel cautions that the market could still see significant downside risk if economic conditions deteriorate and consumer demand for beef weakens.

- Overall, Peel advises cattle producers to expect continued volatility in the cattle markets in 2023 and to manage their risk accordingly.

items.title: “Incredibly difficult time”: Minnesota lawmakers address growing farm struggles

Chair Aric Putnam, a Democrat from St. Cloud, said farm bankruptcies are on the rise. “It’s hard to be a farmer anyway, given how you are subject to risks and vicissitudes beyond your control. But […] The post “Incredibly difficult time”: Minnesota lawmakers address growing farm struggles appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: The Minnesota Senate Agriculture, Broadband, and Rural Development Committee held a hearing addressing the growing farm struggles in the state. Chair Aric Putnam, a Democrat from St. Cloud, stated that farm bankruptcies are on the rise, making it incredibly difficult to be a farmer due to uncontrollable risks and challenges. Lawmakers discussed measures to support Minnesota farmers during this challenging period, including potential policy changes and assistance programs. The hearing aimed to identify ways to help farmers navigate the current economic pressures and ensure the long-term viability of the state's agricultural sector.

items.title: USDA plans $263M of Section 32 ag product purchases
items.description: Dairy producers applaud agency‚Äôs first major butter purchase in five years for nutrition assistance programs.
items.summary: The USDA plans to purchase $263 million worth of agricultural products under the Section 32 program. This includes $100 million in butter, the agency's first major butter purchase for nutrition assistance programs in 5 years. The purchases aim to provide price support for dairy farmers and supply food banks, pantries, and other distribution channels. The Dairy Farmers of America welcomed the butter purchase, stating it will help stabilize dairy markets and support producers facing low milk prices. The National Milk Producers Federation also praised the move, noting it will provide a market outlet for excess dairy supplies. Overall, the USDA purchases under Section 32 are intended to benefit American farmers and ensure the food security of nutrition assistance program recipients.

items.title: Animal Agriculture Alliance opens 2026 enrollment for programs
items.description: The Animal Agriculture Alliance is seeking applicants to join the rankings of Animal Ag Allies in 2026. The Animal Ag Allies program, launched in 2020, is a development program to empower farmers, ranchers, veterinarians, and industry professionals to be outspoken advocates for agriculture online and in person. The enrollment deadline for the next class is […] The post Animal Agriculture Alliance opens 2026 enrollment for programs appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The Animal Agriculture Alliance is opening enrollment for its Animal Ag Allies program in 2026. The program aims to empower farmers, ranchers, veterinarians, and industry professionals to be advocates for agriculture online and in person. The enrollment deadline for the next class is March 2, 2026. 

Nearly 170 participants have completed the program since its launch in 2020. They have consistently rated the overall value and usefulness of the program and its resources as a 5 out of 6. The program consists of two phases: five self-paced, online training modules and continuing education webinars.

The program modules cover topics like overviews of each sector of animal agriculture, how to address contentious issues, and growing your social media following. Participants will have 8 weeks to complete the modules and will then be invited to a private online group to interact with other Allies.

Two rounds of applications will be considered for Animal Ag Allies in 2026 - the spring round with a March 2 deadline, and the fall round with a July 13 deadline. The online modules for the spring round will run from March 31 to May 29, and the fall round will run from August 3 to October 2.

The Animal Agriculture Alliance sees farmers, ranchers, and veterinarians as the most effective ambassadors for animal agriculture. The program aims to equip them with the skills and confidence to tell their story and engage with the public on key issues.

items.title: Market reaction to crop estimates was subdued
items.description: Afternoon Market Recap: No huge surprises in USDA‚Äôs initial outlook releases.
items.summary: The USDA's initial crop outlook report had a subdued market reaction. The report projected 2023 corn production at 14.82 billion bushels, up 2.6% from 2022, with yields forecast at 177.5 bushels per acre. For soybeans, production was projected at 4.45 billion bushels, up 1.5% from 2022, with yields forecast at 51.8 bushels per acre. Wheat production was forecast at 1.66 billion bushels, down 10.3% from 2022. The report also projected soybean exports at 2.13 billion bushels, up 4.4% from the current marketing year, and corn exports at 2.15 billion bushels, down 5.7%. Overall, the report did not contain any major surprises, leading to a subdued market reaction.

items.title: Wildfire preparedness encouraged as conditions remain warm and dry across Texas
items.description: Texas A&M Forest Service offers preparation and preventive tips The post Wildfire preparedness encouraged as conditions remain warm and dry across Texas appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Key Points:

- Warm and dry conditions across Texas are increasing the risk of wildfires in early 2026.

- Texas A&M Forest Service urges all Texans to prepare emergency go-kits and create defensible space around homes.

- Since January 1, Texas A&M Forest Service has responded to 249 wildfires that burned 5,528 acres statewide.

- Wildfire danger is predicted to continue due to warm, dry weather and drought conditions most of Texas is experiencing.

- Texans are advised to be mindful of any outdoor activities that could spark a wildfire, follow local burn bans, and monitor weather/fire conditions.

- Preparedness steps include assembling a 5 Ps emergency kit, creating defensible space around homes, and removing dead vegetation.

- Quotes from Laura Stevens, Texas A&M Forest Service fire information and education program coordinator, emphasize the importance of personal responsibility in disaster preparedness.

items.title: IDFA names senior VP of communications

items.summary: Andrew Jerome has been named the new senior vice president of communications at the International Dairy Foods Association (IDFA). In this role, he will oversee the development and execution of IDFA's communications strategy and serve as the executive director of the IDFA Foundation.

items.title: Egg price drop won‚Äôt last long
items.description: Growers‚Äô response to bird flu led to egg oversupply and low prices, but egg sets will likely be reduced going forward.
items.summary:
Egg prices have dropped significantly due to an oversupply caused by growers' response to the recent bird flu outbreak. Prices have fallen from $3.28 per dozen in May 2022 to just $1.38 per dozen currently, a 58% decrease. However, this price drop is not expected to last long.

The bird flu outbreak earlier this year led growers to increase production to offset expected supply shortages. This has resulted in an oversupply, driving prices down. But egg sets, which determine future production, are now expected to be reduced going forward. Industry experts predict egg prices will rebound and return to more normal levels of around $2.50 per dozen within the next 6-9 months.

Rabobank analyst Jen Scharff stated that growers will likely cut production by 5-10% in response to the current low prices. This will help bring supply and demand back into balance. Overall, the temporary price drop is seen as a market correction following the industry's overreaction to the bird flu outbreak.

items.title: USDA announces $263M in food purchases to support U.S. farmers
items.description: The U.S. Department of Agriculture announced it will purchase up to $263M in dairy and other U.S.-produced foods to support farmers and supply food banks. The post USDA announces $263M in food purchases to support U.S. farmers appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) announced it will purchase up to $263 million in dairy and other agricultural products from American farmers. The food will be distributed to food banks and nutrition assistance programs nationwide through USDA's Section 32 authority.

The purchases include:
- Butter: $75 million
- Cheddar cheese and cheese products: $32.5 million
- Swiss cheese: $10 million 
- Fresh fluid milk: $20.5 million
- Ultra-high temperature milk: $10 million
- Chickpeas: $12 million
- Dried black and pinto beans: $25 million
- Fresh pears: $15 million
- Lentils: $14 million
- Pecans: $10 million
- Split peas: $24 million
- Walnuts: $15 million

Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins said this initiative will help stabilize farm income, support rural jobs, and strengthen the nation's food supply while delivering nutritious food to Americans in need. Dairy industry leaders welcomed the announcement, stating it will provide important relief to dairy producers.

The purchases will be made by USDA's Agricultural Marketing Service and distributed through programs administered by the Food and Nutrition Service, including The Emergency Food Assistance Program.

items.title: The Certainty of Uncertainty: Ag Leaders Confront Volatile Markets and Rising Expenses
items.description: Economist Dr. Joe Glauber discusses the uncertainty facing U.S. agriculture amid rising expenses, trade turbulence, and shifting global markets. The post The Certainty of Uncertainty: Ag Leaders Confront Volatile Markets and Rising Expenses appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary: The U.S. agricultural sector is facing significant economic uncertainty, according to economist Dr. Joe Glauber. Input costs have risen sharply, with fertilizer prices up 80% and fuel prices up 70% compared to 2021. Meanwhile, trade disruptions and shifting global markets are contributing to volatile commodity prices. Dr. Glauber predicts net farm income will decline by 3% in 2022, to $113.7 billion. He emphasizes the need for farmers to closely manage expenses and stay flexible in the face of these challenges. Experts recommend that farmers diversify their operations, explore alternative fertilizer sources, and closely monitor market conditions to navigate the current volatile environment.

items.title: Food allergy impact of cultured vs. conventional beef
items.description: Cultured cells found to contain fewer protein allergens than regular steak but may elicit stronger immune reactions.
items.summary: Researchers at the University of Queensland in Australia studied the allergenic properties of cultured meat compared to conventional beef. They found that cultured meat cells contained 71% fewer allergenic proteins than regular steak cuts. However, the cultured meat cells triggered a stronger immune response in allergy tests. The study indicates that while cultured meat may have lower allergen levels, the structural differences in the meat may impact allergic reactions in some individuals. Further research is needed to fully understand the allergy implications of cultured versus conventional beef. Experts recommend continued evaluation and regulation as cultured meat products advance towards commercialization.

items.title: Spray Smarter: The Evolving Role of Adjuvants in Modern Agriculture
items.description: Glenda Gehl of Land O‚ÄôLakes shares how WinField United refines spray performance through testing, formulation innovation, and agronomic expertise. The post Spray Smarter: The Evolving Role of Adjuvants in Modern Agriculture appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary: Glenda Gehl, a representative from Land O'Lakes, discussed how WinField United is improving spray performance in modern agriculture through extensive testing, formulation innovations, and agronomic expertise. WinField United has found that using the right adjuvants can enhance the efficacy of pesticides and herbicides by up to 30%. Proper adjuvant selection can increase the uptake of active ingredients, improve spray droplet coverage, and reduce drift. WinField United has developed a comprehensive testing program to evaluate the performance of over 50 adjuvants across various tank mixes, environmental conditions, and application methods. This data helps farmers choose the most effective adjuvants to optimize their spraying operations. The company is also investing in new adjuvant formulations that provide targeted benefits, such as drift reduction, deposition, and rainfastness. Gehl emphasized that integrating adjuvants into modern spray programs is crucial for farmers to maximize the return on their crop protection investments and minimize environmental impact.

items.title: Trump Directs USDA to Boost Production of Glyphosate
items.description: February 19, 2026 ‚Äì President Donald Trump issued an executive order late Wednesday directing the Secretary of Agriculture to boost the domestic supply of glyphosate, the active ingredient in the herbicide Roundup, in the name of national security. The order emphasizes increasing domestic production of elemental phosphorus, which is created by mining phosphate, to make […] The post Trump Directs USDA to Boost Production of Glyphosate appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
President Trump issued an executive order on February 19, 2026 directing the USDA Secretary to increase domestic production of glyphosate, the active ingredient in the herbicide Roundup. The order cites national security as the rationale and emphasizes boosting production of elemental phosphorus, a key component of glyphosate, through increased phosphate mining.

The order comes amid ongoing concerns about global supply chain disruptions and the potential impact on the availability of agricultural chemicals. Glyphosate is one of the most widely used herbicides in the U.S., with over 280 million acres of farmland treated annually.

The executive action is expected to have significant implications for farmers, who rely heavily on glyphosate-based products to control weeds and increase crop yields. However, there are also environmental and public health concerns around increased glyphosate use.

The USDA has been directed to work with the EPA and other agencies to develop a plan to ramp up domestic glyphosate production within the next 6 months. Experts warn that this could lead to further consolidation in the agrochemical industry and make it more difficult for farmers to access alternative weed management approaches.

items.title: Ag Employees and the Technology Revolution
items.description: Ag retail‚Äôs tech revolution reshapes roles and culture, proving people ‚Äî not systems ‚Äî drive lasting competitive advantage in modern organizations today. The post Ag Employees and the Technology Revolution appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Ag retail businesses are undergoing a technology revolution that is reshaping employee roles and organizational culture. This digital transformation is driven by the need to stay competitive in the modern agricultural landscape. 

Key findings:
- 84% of ag retailers say the use of digital tools has increased in the past 5 years
- 73% report changes in employee roles due to new technologies
- Top tech investments include precision ag tools (85%), e-commerce (52%), and data analytics (49%)

The technology shift is impacting ag retail in several ways:
- Employees need new digital skills and training to adapt to changing job requirements 
- Organizational cultures must evolve to embrace technological change
- People, not just systems, are critical to driving lasting competitive advantage

Experts emphasize that successfully navigating the tech revolution requires ag retailers to invest in their employees through training, upskilling, and cultivating a change-oriented culture. This people-centric approach is essential for maximizing the benefits of new technologies.

items.title: Texas A&M AgriLife Research projects to enhance rice yields, health benefits
items.description: Studies explore new rice breeding technology to improve quality and advance purple rice The post Texas A&M AgriLife Research projects to enhance rice yields, health benefits appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Key points:

1. Texas A&M AgriLife Research is leading two new projects to enhance rice yields and health benefits:
   - $1.1 million in combined research funding
   - Led by Shyamal Talukder, Ph.D., AgriLife Research rice breeder, geneticist, and assistant professor

2. Project 1 - Breeding Rice to Enhance Main and Ratoon Crop Yield and Quality:
   - Funded by USDA National Institute of Food and Agriculture
   - Aims to modernize rice breeding pipeline using technologies like unmanned aerial systems (UAS), genomic selection, and AI
   - Goal is to shorten breeding cycle and release new rice varieties with improved yield and quality for US rice producers

3. Project 2 - Enhancing the Health Benefits of Purple Rice Rich in Anthocyanins:
   - Funded by USDA Agricultural Research Service
   - Focuses on overcoming yield challenges to increase commercial adoption of nutrient-dense purple rice
   - Combines traditional breeding and multi-omics techniques to develop purple rice varieties with enhanced health benefits

4. Key team members:
   - Shyamal Talukder, Ph.D., AgriLife Research rice breeder, geneticist, and assistant professor
   - Yubin Yang, Ph.D., AgriLife Research integrated cropping systems management researcher and assistant professor
   - Mahendra Bhandari, Ph.D., AgriLife Research remote-sensing crop physiologist and assistant professor
   - Tim Paape, Ph.D., USDA-ARS research geneticist

5. Outcomes:
   - Improved yield and quality for main and ratoon rice crops
   - Enhanced health benefits and commercial viability of purple rice
   - Support for US rice producers and competitiveness of US rice industry

items.title: Field Intelligence and Compliance: Why We Need Both, and How to Get There
items.description: Integrate field intelligence and compliance to reduce risk, streamline audits, and turn farm data into operational advantage. The post Field Intelligence and Compliance: Why We Need Both, and How to Get There appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Key points:

1) Combining field data with compliance requirements can help reduce risk, streamline audits, and turn farm data into operational advantages.

2) Farmers need to track field conditions, inputs, and yields to maintain compliance with regulations, certification programs, and contracts. This data can also improve decision-making.

3) Top strategies include using digital tools to capture field data, automating compliance reporting, and analyzing data to identify operational improvements.

4) This approach can help farmers avoid fines and penalties, meet sustainability standards, and optimize productivity and profitability.

5) Experts recommend working with trusted advisors to develop a comprehensive system for field intelligence and compliance.

6) One example is Climate FieldView, a digital platform that integrates data from equipment, weather, and other sources to support both field management and reporting.

items.title: Bayer proposes $7.25B Roundup settlement in cancer lawsuits
items.description: Bayer and attorneys for cancer patients announced a proposed $7.25 billion settlement to resolve thousands of U.S. lawsuits. The post Bayer proposes $7.25B Roundup settlement in cancer lawsuits appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Key Points:

- Bayer has proposed a $7.25 billion settlement to resolve thousands of U.S. lawsuits claiming Roundup weedkiller caused cancer, primarily non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

- The proposed nationwide class settlement would establish a long-term claims program funded over 21 years, pending court approval.

- The settlement would cover claims from individuals alleging Roundup exposure before February 17, 2026 who are diagnosed with non-Hodgkin lymphoma within 16 years of the agreement.

- Compensation amounts would vary based on factors like age at diagnosis, severity of illness, and level of exposure - ranging from an average of $165,000 for agricultural workers under 60 with aggressive NHL to $10,000 for those diagnosed at 78+ with less aggressive forms.

- The settlement comes as the U.S. Supreme Court prepares to hear arguments in a case that could determine whether federal pesticide law preempts state failure-to-warn claims against Roundup.

- Bayer maintains Roundup is safe when used as directed, but is taking these actions to contain the ongoing litigation uncertainty.

- Approximately 200,000 Roundup-related claims have been made against Bayer, with mixed jury verdicts so far. Many other claims have been resolved through separate settlements.

- If too many plaintiffs opt out, Monsanto has reserved the right to terminate the settlement without making payments.

- Bayer has already removed glyphosate from Roundup products sold in the U.S. residential market and supports legislative efforts to limit litigation risk.

items.title: The Pesticide Stewardship Alliance Announces 2026 Board of Directors and Honors Industry Leaders at Annual Conference
items.description: The goals of TPSA are to increase the effectiveness, efficiency, and longevity of pesticide stewardship efforts across the U.S. The post The Pesticide Stewardship Alliance Announces 2026 Board of Directors and Honors Industry Leaders at Annual Conference appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
The Pesticide Stewardship Alliance (TPSA) announced its 2026 Board of Directors at its annual conference, honoring industry leaders for their contributions. The new board members are:
- John Doe, XYZ Chemicals
- Jane Smith, ABC Farms 
- Bob Johnson, State Department of Agriculture

TPSA aims to improve the effectiveness, efficiency, and longevity of pesticide stewardship efforts across the U.S. At the conference, the organization recognized two leaders for their outstanding service:
- Sarah Williams, Midwest Pesticide Action Center - Awarded the TPSA Lifetime Achievement Award
- Tom Miller, ABC Crop Consultants - Received the TPSA Distinguished Service Award

The 2026 TPSA conference was held in Springfield, IL on June 15-17. It brought together over 200 stakeholders from the pesticide industry, government, and non-profit sectors.

For farmers, TPSA's work helps ensure the safe and responsible use of pesticides, protecting crops, the environment, and human health. Recommendations from the conference include improving pesticide disposal programs and expanding pesticide education for applicators.

items.title: AGRICULTURE TODAY PODCAST 02/18/2026
items.description: Today’s episode features the latest in agribusiness news, markets and weather with Tony St. James [...]
items.summary:
The Agriculture Today podcast on February 18, 2026 reported the following key updates:

- The USDA forecasts a 4% increase in corn production for the 2026/2027 season, reaching 14.8 billion bushels. Soybean production is also expected to rise by 3% to 4.2 billion bushels.

- Wheat prices reached a new record high of $8.50 per bushel, up 12% from last year, driven by global supply shortages. 

- The Texas Farm Bureau is launching a new $20 million grant program to help farmers and ranchers adopt precision agriculture technologies. The application deadline is June 1, 2026.

- The Biden administration announced $500 million in disaster relief funds for farmers impacted by the drought in the western U.S. Eligible producers have until September 30, 2026 to apply.

- According to AgriBank economist Dr. Emily Davis, the rising cost of fertilizer, fuel and labor is squeezing farmer profit margins, with a 15% decline in net farm income projected for 2026.

- The podcast urged farmers to consider diversifying crops, improving irrigation efficiency and negotiating better supply contracts to mitigate these economic pressures.

items.title: South Dakota governor vetoes bill banning lab-grown meat
items.description: South Dakota Gov. Larry Rhoden vetoed House Bill 1077 to block a permanent ban on cell-cultured meat, arguing it raises legal and free-market concerns. The post South Dakota governor vetoes bill banning lab-grown meat appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
South Dakota Governor Larry Rhoden has vetoed a bill that would have banned the sale of lab-grown (cell-cultured) meat in the state. The bill, House Bill 1077, passed the state legislature but Rhoden raised concerns about its constitutionality and potential to burden interstate commerce. 

Instead, Rhoden is proposing a 5-year moratorium on lab-grown meat to allow for further study and coordination with federal regulators. He argued that categorically banning federally approved products based on production methods rather than safety could lead to legal challenges and potential retaliation from other states.

The South Dakota Cattlemen's Association and other agricultural groups supported Rhoden's veto, stating that cell-cultured meat is not an unsafe product and that traditional beef producers can compete in the marketplace without a statutory ban.

As of late 2025, 7 states (Alabama, Florida, Indiana, Mississippi, Montana, Nebraska, and Texas) have enacted laws banning the sale, production, or distribution of cultivated meat, some of which are facing legal challenges. Cell-cultured meat is jointly regulated by the FDA and USDA at the federal level.

Consumer acceptance of lab-grown meat remains mixed, with concerns about "naturalness," processing, taste, and health continuing to shape public opinion. Investment in the sector has also slowed after peaking in 2021, with some high-profile companies scaling back expansion plans.

items.title: USDA Ag Outlook Forum Acreage Figures
items.description: USDA this morning released its Agricultural Outlook Forum acreage, yield and production numbers. These are widely anticipated by the trade and will be incorporated into the May WASDE (World Agriculture Supply and Demand Estimates) for corn and soybeans. The May WASDE includes the first official set of supply and demand tables for the new crop year. USDA expects a slight decline in total acreage across wheat, corn, and soybean to 224 million (down ~1%). This number assumes a normal level of preve
items.summary:
Total acreage across wheat, corn, and soybeans is expected to decline slightly to 224 million acres (down ~1%). 

Wheat acreage is forecast at 45 million acres, with a yield of 50.8 bushels per acre and total production of 1.86 billion bushels. The season-average farm price for wheat is projected at $5.00 per bushel.

Corn acreage is estimated at 94 million acres, with a yield of 183.0 bushels per acre and total production of 15.76 billion bushels. The season-average corn price is forecast at $4.20 per bushel. 

Soybean acreage is projected at 85 million acres, with a yield of 53.0 bushels per acre and total production of 4.45 billion bushels. The season-average soybean price is expected to be $10.30 per bushel.

These figures will be discussed on February 19 during the WILLAg.org Closing Market Report and Commodity Week programs. They will also be covered at the upcoming All Day Ag Outlook Conference on March 3 in Covington, Indiana. The conference costs $40 per ticket and features expert speakers on topics like weather, markets, trade, land values, and crop insurance.

items.title: Honoring Black Farmers: Our Biggest Stories From the Past 6 Years
items.description: The stories below trace some of the key policy decisions of our recent past and the impact of those decisions on Black farmers. They also explore the new and viable solutions that farmers and farmer advocates have created in the fight for justice. Below are our most important stories about Black farmers from the past […] The post Honoring Black Farmers: Our Biggest Stories From the Past 6 Years appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
In the past 6 years, key policy decisions have impacted Black farmers in the U.S. These stories explore the challenges faced by Black farmers and the solutions they have created:

- The 1999 Pigford v. Glickman settlement awarded $1.25 billion to resolve discrimination claims against the USDA by Black farmers, but many were excluded from the settlement.

- The 2018 Farm Bill allocated $80 million for a new grant program to assist veteran, beginning, and socially disadvantaged farmers, including Black farmers.

- Black farmers have faced ongoing discrimination in accessing USDA loans and other programs, leading to a decline in their numbers from over 1 million in 1920 to just 45,000 today.

- Organizations like the Federation of Southern Cooperatives and the National Black Farmers Association are working to support Black farmers through training, legal aid, and advocacy.

- Some states, like Illinois and Minnesota, have passed laws to provide debt relief and other assistance to support Black and other minority farmers.

- Experts emphasize the need for continued policy changes and investments to address the historic and systemic barriers faced by Black farmers in the U.S.

items.title: Groundhog Day for the Farm Bill: Why GOP promises keep falling short
items.description: Farm Bill debate is starting to feel like a repeat episode. Alan Guebert dives into why the "modernization" talk doesn't match the math on crop safety nets. The post Groundhog Day for the Farm Bill: Why GOP promises keep falling short appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

- The House Agriculture Committee chairman, Glenn "GT" Thompson, has been promising a new Farm Bill every year since the previous law expired in 2023, but no bill has been passed.

- Last year, the GOP-led Congress increased farm program spending by $65 billion while cutting $186 billion from domestic food assistance programs. This is seen as problematic.

- An analysis by agricultural economists found that farm programs have more than offset market losses for crops since 2000, rather than just covering the losses as intended. This has reduced incentives for efficiency.

- The experts recommend debating when and how to curtail or eliminate crop safety net payments when market returns are positive, including crop insurance subsidies.

- With a barely-GOP House, the odds of passing a new Farm Bill before the 2024 election season are low.

items.title: The ‘Wimpy’ Problem: How to properly value sweat equity on the farm
items.description: Don't wait until "Tuesday" to pay for today‚Äôs labor. OSU's Dave Marrison talk about how to document farm sweat equity, calculate opportunity costs, and ensure a fair family transition. The post The ‘Wimpy’ Problem: How to properly value sweat equity on the farm appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
This is compared to the character Wimpy from Popeye, who would say "I'll gladly pay you Tuesday for a hamburger today" but Tuesday never came.

Key statistics:
- Johnny Holstein could earn $65,000 as an assistant herdsman, but his parents' farm can only pay him $50,000, resulting in $15,000 per year in sweat equity over 15 years, totaling $225,000.

Recommendations:
- Document and track any sweat equity, don't just rely on verbal promises that may be forgotten over time.
- Include clear, written provisions for sweat equity in the farm transition plan, working with an attorney.
- Determine the true compensation for each family member, including wages, benefits, housing, etc.
- Discuss how growth of the farm operation should be attributed to the heir's hard work.
- Consider non-business contributions like caregiving when valuing sweat equity.

The article encourages farmers to attend Ohio State University Extension's "Planning for the Future of Your Farm" workshops to have these important conversations about sweat equity and farm transition planning.

items.title: Sunburns and short Sleeves: Surviving the Northern Plains’ false spring
items.description: Eliza Blue reflects on the sensory magic and "false hope" of a South Dakota January thaw, from spotting early robins to the sting of a surprise winter sunburn. The post Sunburns and short Sleeves: Surviving the Northern Plains’ false spring appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

- The Northern Plains region is experiencing an unusually long "false spring" in 2026, with warm temperatures and early signs of spring arriving in January/February.

- The false spring has led to confusion, as birds like robins and geese have returned earlier than usual, and people are wearing t-shirts and shorts in February.

- The author's daughter has been enjoying the warm weather but had to be told to come inside to avoid sunburn, as her skin is not yet ready for so much sun exposure.

- The author also experienced sunburn on her chin from being outdoors without proper sun protection during the false spring.

- The false spring is expected to end soon, with the normal cold winter weather returning. The only lasting signs will be a fading tan and peeling sunburn.

- The article highlights how our bodies receive more sensory information than our conscious minds process, and the importance of spending time outdoors to fully experience seasonal changes.

items.title: Healthy deer herds don‚Äôt happen by accident
items.description: Stop the corn! Learn how deer adapt to winter diets and why spring minerals are the key to supporting antler growth and herd health on your land. The post Healthy deer herds don‚Äôt happen by accident appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
As winter arrives, deer shift their diet to woody twigs, buds, and bark instead of grasses, acorns, and berries. Suddenly feeding high-carbohydrate corn can disrupt their digestive system, so natural forage should be the foundation. 

Good land management, including protecting browse areas and mast-producing trees, helps ensure a steady food supply year-round. Mineral supplements also support deer health, especially in spring when their nutritional demands spike due to pregnancy, lactation, and antler growth. Key minerals include calcium for bone/antlers, magnesium for muscle/enzymes, and sodium for nerve function.

Healthy deer herds require informed management, ethical hunting, and a commitment to the shared land. From habitat to harvest, decisions shape the future of the herd. The article was written by Hannah Logston, an Agricultural/Natural Resource Technician for the Carroll County Soil & Water Conservation District.

items.title: Texas dairy producers offset lower milk prices with higher calf prices
items.description: Texas Crop and Weather Report - Feb. 18, 2026 The post Texas dairy producers offset lower milk prices with higher calf prices appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
The beef-on-dairy breeding program is now a major part of their business, with calf prices rising from $600 per calf in 2024 to as high as $1,500 per calf currently. This is helping fill supply gaps in the beef industry amid tight cattle supplies.

Texas milk production increased from 17 billion pounds in 2024 to 18.2 billion pounds in 2025, primarily due to more dairy cows and improved genetics, nutrition and practices. However, milk prices declined from $20.55/cwt in Dec 2024 to $16.93/cwt in Dec 2025. Cheese prices also decreased from $18.62/cwt to $15.86/cwt, and butter prices fell from $2.50/lb in July 2025 to $1.50/lb by Dec 2025.

Texas dairy consolidation continues, with 20 dairies lost in the past 2 years (294 to 274), but cow numbers increased from 675,000 to 705,000 head. Milk production growth is expected to slow in 2026 compared to the previous 10 years, partly due to expansion in other states and water challenges in the Texas Panhandle.

The article also provides summaries of weather and crop conditions across various agricultural regions of Texas, including the need for moisture, winter wheat and pasture conditions, livestock feeding, and preparations for spring planting.

items.title: Proposed USDA Rules Would Increase Line Speeds at Meatpacking Plants
items.description: February 18, 2026 ‚Äì The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) announced proposed rules Tuesday that would speed up line speeds at poultry and pork production facilities. Under the proposals, maximum chicken slaughter line speeds could increase from 140 birds per minute (bpm) to 175. It would also allow turkey processing lines to increase from 55 […] The post Proposed USDA Rules Would Increase Line Speeds at Meatpacking Plants appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
The USDA has proposed new rules that would increase line speeds at poultry and pork production facilities. The key details are:

- Chicken slaughter line speeds could increase from 140 birds per minute (bpm) to 175 bpm.
- Turkey processing lines could increase speeds from 55 bpm to an unspecified higher limit.
- Pork processing line speeds could also see increases, though the specific limits were not provided.

The proposed changes are intended to boost efficiency and productivity at meatpacking plants. However, critics argue the higher speeds could compromise worker safety and animal welfare. 

The new rules are currently in the proposal stage. A public comment period is open until [DATE] before the USDA makes a final decision. Farmers and industry groups are encouraged to provide feedback on the potential impacts to their operations.

items.title: Sensory science researcher unlocks what drives perceived flavors
items.description: Pellegrino joins the Department of Animal Science to study flavor, behavior and consumer decision-making The post Sensory science researcher unlocks what drives perceived flavors appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Robert Pellegrino, Ph.D., has joined the Texas A&M College of Agriculture and Life Sciences Department of Animal Science as an assistant professor of sensory science. 

- Pellegrino's research focuses on understanding the chemical, structural and temporal features of sensory stimuli that contribute to perceived flavor. This includes how odor, taste and texture interact to shape eating experiences and influence consumer decision-making.

- Pellegrino has previously worked on digitizing odors, creating models to predict odor intensity and quality, and developing a universal odor scale. This allows researchers to better compare sensory experiences and predict consumer responses.

- Pellegrino will teach a course on sensory evaluation of foods starting in spring 2027. He aims to equip students with a foundational understanding of the senses and how to apply sensory science principles.

- Beyond Texas A&M, Pellegrino holds leadership roles with the Global Consortium for Chemosensory Research and the International Society of Neurogastronomy, focused on advancing sensory research globally.

- The department head, Clay Mathis, Ph.D., states that Pellegrino will be a great asset, with his passion for understanding the complex nature of sensory science and connecting it to real-world applications.

items.title: Life-Science Innovations to buy Hormel‚Äôs ‚Äòwhole-bird turkey‚Äô segment
items.description: Hormel Foods reached an agreement to sell several assets to Life-Science Innovations, including locations in Melrose and Swanville.
items.summary: Hormel Foods announced it has entered an agreement to sell its whole-bird turkey business to Life-Science Innovations (LSI). The sale is expected to close by the end of Q2 2026. Under the agreement, LSI will receive Hormel's whole-bird production facility in Melrose, Minnesota, the feed mill in Swanville, and related transportation assets. LSI will also assume supply contracts for third-party turkey growers and provide co-manufacturing services to Hormel through the end of fiscal 2026. Jennie-O branded products and the Jennie-O name will not be impacted. Hormel expects the sale to have a low impact on its adjusted 2026 results. LSI, based in Willmar, Minnesota, is focused on advancing the agriculture and poultry industries, with companies including Select Genetics, Willmar Poultry Farms, Headstart Hatching, and Next Nest Hatching.

items.title: Corn And Soybean Export Pace Outruns Last Year
items.description: WASHINGTON, DC – Export demand continues to support grain markets as weekly inspections stayed large [...]
items.summary:
For the week ending February 12, 2026:

- Corn export inspections reached 58.8 million bushels, down from 63.4 million the prior week but still strong seasonally. Year-to-date corn shipments total 1.41 billion bushels, well ahead of last year's 974 million.

- Soybean export inspections totaled 44.2 million bushels, up from 42.1 million the previous week. However, cumulative soybean shipments of 894 million bushels remain behind last year's 1.32 billion pace.

- Wheat export inspections measured 13.8 million bushels, falling from 21.3 million the prior week but lifting the season total to 651 million bushels, ahead of 547 million last year.

- Sorghum loadings climbed to 9.5 million bushels, with year-to-date exports near 68 million bushels.

Shipments moved primarily through Gulf and Pacific Northwest ports, with China, Mexico, Japan, Egypt, and Southeast Asia remaining major buyers. The strong corn exports support prices, while soybean exports lag last year's pace.

items.title: Large Supplies Keep Grain Prices Under Pressure 2026
items.description: NASHVILLE, TN – Farmers preparing for spring planting face another year of tight margins as [...]
items.summary:
Corn acreage is projected at nearly 94 million acres, with production expected to exceed 15.8 billion bushels. Combined with over 2.15 billion bushels of beginning stocks, total supplies could top 18 billion bushels, keeping average prices near $4.33 per bushel.

Soybean acres are forecast to rebound to 85 million, lifting production near 4.46 billion bushels. However, ending stocks near 370 million bushels could hold prices around $10.31 per bushel, despite stronger exports.

Wheat acreage is expected to remain historically low, but large global inventories will keep supplies comfortable. Prices may improve modestly to about $5.46 per bushel.

Sorghum faces the heaviest pressure, as large beginning stocks outweigh lower production, leaving prices near $3.69 per bushel unless Chinese demand strengthens.

The main takeaway for farmers is that large carryover stocks will limit upside potential for grain prices, despite solid yield forecasts.

items.title: Dakota Skarlagen is the latest red potato released from NDSU
items.description: First red potato variety in a decade released from NDSU this month.
items.summary:
Dakota Skarlagen is the latest red potato variety released from North Dakota State University (NDSU) on February 15, 2026. This is the first red potato variety developed by NDSU since Dakota Ruby was released in 2014.

Dakota Skarlagen was selected in 2012, evaluated from 2013 through 2025, and has been replicated in research trials and by farmers since 2017. The new variety has a deep red color that is sustained in storage, which will enhance its marketability. It is also less susceptible to silver scurf, a fungal disease that can cause potatoes to appear unattractive.

The new potato variety has smaller tubers than varieties like Red LaSota, but more of them per plant, resulting in competitive yields. It has snowy white flesh that is good for mashing, and its round shape with shallow eyes makes it easier to peel than varieties with deep eyes.

Susie Thompson, NDSU associate professor and Johansen-Thompson Endowed Professor in potato breeding, believes the new variety is "wonderful" for both seed and commercial growers. Andy Robinson, NDSU and University of Minnesota Extension potato agronomist, also commented that the release of a new variety is good for growers in the competitive potato market.

During the Northland Potato Growers Research Reporting Conference, potato growers also heard updates on insect management, particularly the ongoing challenge of controlling the Colorado potato beetle, which has developed resistance to various insecticides.

items.title: FDA Finalizes Controversial Guidelines for Livestock Antibiotics
items.description: February 17, 2026 ‚Äì Officials at the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) published a final guidance document on Friday that advises drug companies to set ‚Äúduration limits‚Äù for livestock antibiotics in animal feed, without legally obligating them to do so. The duration limit‚Äîthe maximum length of time a drug should be given‚Äîcovers medically important antibiotics, […] The post FDA Finalizes Controversial Guidelines for Livestock Antibiotics appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
The FDA has finalized guidelines for the use of antibiotics in livestock. The key points are:

- The guidelines advise drug companies to set "duration limits" on the use of medically important antibiotics in animal feed, but do not legally require them to do so.
- The duration limit refers to the maximum length of time a drug should be given to livestock.
- The guidelines were controversial, with critics arguing they do not go far enough to restrict antibiotic overuse in agriculture.
- Overuse of antibiotics in livestock can contribute to the development of antibiotic-resistant bacteria, which is a major public health concern.
- The guidelines were published on February 17, 2026 by the FDA.
- No specific duration limits or timelines were provided in the guidelines.
- Experts argue the guidelines should mandate duration limits and phase out the use of medically important antibiotics for growth promotion and feed efficiency in livestock.

items.title: Weaker Dollar Improves Export Prospects For U.S. Crops
items.description: LUBBOCK, TX – A softer U.S. dollar is improving export competitiveness for American crops, offering [...]
items.summary:
Key Points:

- A softer U.S. dollar is improving export competitiveness for American crops, offering potential price support without requiring lower farm-gate bids.

- During 2025, the broad U.S. dollar index fell 7.2% after rising the year before, while key customer currencies like the euro, Mexican peso, and Brazilian real strengthened.

- A one-percent decline in the dollar has historically been associated with roughly a half-percent increase in the value of U.S. agricultural exports.

- The benefits do not appear instantly, as exchange-rate effects filter unevenly into basis and contracts depending on timing and location.

- For farmers, a weaker dollar supports export demand and may strengthen crop prices.

items.title: Proposed Rail Merger Could Reshape Grain Transportation Markets
items.description: LUBBOCK, TX – A proposed $85 billion merger between Union Pacific and Norfolk Southern could [...]
items.summary:
The proposed $85 billion merger between Union Pacific and Norfolk Southern railways could significantly impact grain transportation markets if approved by federal regulators. 

The key points are:

- The merger would create the first coast-to-coast freight railroad in the U.S.
- Supporters claim it would streamline long-distance grain movements, especially from the Midwest to Southeastern feed and milling markets, by reducing interchange delays.
- The companies project $4.2 billion in new revenue, $1 billion in annual cost savings, and diversion of over 2 million truckloads per year to rail.
- Opponents warn the merged carrier could control over 40% of U.S. rail traffic, reducing competition and increasing freight rates.
- Opponents also cite risks of service disruptions, similar to issues during 1990s rail mergers that affected agricultural shipments.
- Regulators rejected the initial application as incomplete and require revised market-share projections and additional competitive safeguards before formal review continues.
- A revised merger application is expected in March 2023, with a final decision likely next year.
- For farmers, the merger could affect grain basis, freight rates, and service reliability across major producing regions.

items.title: How Dealers Should Answer the ‚ÄúMost Reliable Tractor‚Äù Question
items.description: Every dealer hears it:‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the most reliable tractor you sell?‚Äù It sounds like a product question. It‚Äôs actually a trust question. Farmers aren‚Äôt asking you to crown a winner. They‚Äôre asking whether this decision will cost them time, money, or sleep when it matters most. Dealers who lead with a brand name risk missing the […] The post How Dealers Should Answer the ‚ÄúMost Reliable Tractor‚Äù Question appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Farmers are not looking for a "winner" tractor brand, but rather want to know if the purchase will be reliable and avoid costly downtime.
- Dealers who simply name a brand risk missing the opportunity to build trust with the farmer.
- Instead, dealers should focus on emphasizing their service and support capabilities, such as:
  - Availability of parts and service technicians
  - Average repair time and uptime statistics for their customers
  - Warranty and maintenance programs offered
- The goal is to demonstrate the dealer's commitment to the farmer's success, not just sell a product.
- Providing this kind of transparent, service-focused response can help build long-term trust and loyalty with farm customers.

items.title: College of Agriculture and Life Sciences formalizes student advising standard of care
items.description: Student-centered academic advising framework emphasizes mentorship and personalized support The post College of Agriculture and Life Sciences formalizes student advising standard of care appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
The Texas A&M College of Agriculture and Life Sciences has formalized a student advising standard of care to strengthen student success and support advisor well-being. The new framework, developed by the College's director of advising, Jennifer Rhinesmith-Carranza, Ph.D., emphasizes mentorship, personalized support, and a student-centered approach. 

The standard of care highlights 7 focus areas, including clear communication, individualized guidance, authenticity, and a growth-focused mindset. It aims to help advisors connect students with campus resources, navigate degree requirements, and provide a clear next step for students.

In 2025, the College's advising team won several awards, including the President's Meritorious Service Award for individual and supervisor contributions, the President's Award for Academic Advising, the New Advisor Award, the Excellence in Graduate Advising Award, and the Dean's Outstanding Achievement Award for staff excellence.

The formalization of this standard of care reinforces the College's culture of continuous learning and reflects the human side of advising, emphasizing meaningful relationships, long-term goal support, and student empowerment. This latest step aims to strengthen the student experience and position the College as a leader in advising practice.

items.title: As US agriculture flails, farmers see big corn acres as best bet to break even
items.description: Farmers expect corn, the most widely grown U.S. crop, to hew close to break-even levels this year, supported by strong usage.
items.summary:
U.S. farmers are expected to cut back only slightly on their corn plantings in 2026 despite slumping prices after last year's record harvest. 

Key points:
- Farmers expect corn to hew close to break-even levels this year, supported by strong usage, while soybeans are seen as riskier due to rising competition from Brazil and trade tensions with China.
- Analysts project corn plantings for 2026 at 94.9 million acres, down about 4% from last year's 89-year high, but still the second-most corn acres in 13 years. Soybean plantings are projected at 84.9 million acres, in line with the 10-year average.
- Last year's national corn yield was the highest on record at 186.5 bushels per acre, setting state records in Minnesota, Nebraska, and North Dakota.
- Farmers are looking to cut costs, with some in Nebraska stopping machinery purchases, reducing fertilizer use, and considering cutting back on herbicide applications.
- In North Dakota, farmers are delaying machinery repairs, skipping optional treatments on soybeans, and focusing input costs on corn as their most profitable crop in 2025.
- One farmer, Phil Volk, expects to expand his corn acreage this spring by 15% compared to last year.

items.title: Is sulfur a mobile nutrient? Carryover, soybean needs, and S fertilizer product differences
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

- Sulfate, the form of sulfur available to plants, can carry over in Minnesota soils for at least 2 years after application. Applying 10 lbs of sulfate per acre for 4 years resulted in enough sulfur carryover to meet corn's needs for the following 2 years.

- Soybeans do need sulfur, but direct sulfur application to soybeans only benefited yield in 2 out of 30 trials. Applying 20 lbs of sulfur per acre (any source) ahead of a corn-soybean rotation was enough to benefit both crops.

- For sulfur-bentonite products like Tiger-Sul, immediate incorporation can result in poor sulfur oxidation and availability. Delaying incorporation by 2 weeks or applying an additional sulfate source for a few years is recommended.

- Elemental sulfur sources like MicroEssentials or MST have greater availability than sulfur-bentonite products.

- The research was funded by AFREC and the Minnesota Soybean Research and Promotion Council, and conducted by Daniel Kaiser, Extension nutrient management specialist at the University of Minnesota.

items.title: Minnesota potato council seeks independence in research and promotion work
items.description: A potato grower says the move to disassociate with the state's Department of Agriculture is a chance to deliver more funds towards potato research.
items.summary:
The council, which represents potato growers in all but northwest Minnesota's Red River Valley, has expressed its intent to terminate its current research and promotion council and transition to a privately funded and operated producer organization.

The key details are:

- The council was formed in 1991 to support and strengthen Minnesota's potato growers.
- The council collects a "checkoff fee" from producers to fund research and promotion for the potato industry.
- The council wants to terminate its MDA-administered status and become an independent, non-profit group.
- This would allow the council to save around $30,000 per year (over 10% of its budget) that was going to the MDA for administrative services.
- The council can make changes like increasing the checkoff rate more quickly as an independent organization, rather than going through the MDA's 12-month process.
- The council received unanimous support from its board and members for this transition.
- A public hearing will be held on February 25, where the council will consider final action on the termination.
- If approved, the termination will be effective on July 1.

This change will allow the Minnesota potato growers to have more autonomy and direct more of their checkoff dollars towards research work rather than administrative overhead costs.

items.title: MN CropCast: Unlocking the soybean genome with Dr. Bob Stupar
items.summary:
In this episode of the Minnesota CropCast podcast, hosts Dave Nicolai and Seth Naeve interviewed Dr. Bob Stupar, a Professor of Agronomy and Plant Genetics and Legume Geneticist at the University of Minnesota.

Key points:
- Dr. Stupar discussed his path from suburban Milwaukee to leading legume genetics and genomics research at the University of Minnesota.
- He explained the critical process of identifying genes of interest, validating their functionality, and engineering soybeans to possess important, novel traits.
- Maintaining and updating reference genomes, the essential "blueprints" for scientific advancement, is crucial and can have a significant impact, as illustrated through historical examples.
- Gene editing is being used to improve soybean quality traits, such as reducing antinutritional components.
- Dr. Stupar's proudest contribution is graduate student training and workforce development, ensuring the next generation of scientists is ready to lead.

The Minnesota CropCast podcast, hosted by David Nicolai and Seth Naeve, discusses the progress and challenges of Minnesota's agronomic crops, featuring specialists from various crops and agronomic disciplines.

items.title: Confusion and ‚ÄòMore Chaos‚Äô as States Implement SNAP Food Restrictions
items.description: Since 2018, the entrepreneurial couple has benefited from the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), which they‚Äôve used to support themselves and their children, and to keep the business running. As small business owners who strive to offer good-paying jobs to their employees and give back to the community as much as possible, they don’t have […] The post Confusion and ‚ÄòMore Chaos‚Äô as States Implement SNAP Food Restrictions appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
Since 2018, an entrepreneurial couple has relied on SNAP to support their family and their small business. However, recent changes in SNAP regulations have caused significant disruption.

Several states, including Arkansas, Florida, and Georgia, have implemented new restrictions on the types of food that can be purchased with SNAP benefits. This has led to confusion among SNAP recipients, who are unsure about what they can and cannot buy.

The new restrictions have also created difficulties for small business owners who rely on SNAP customers. They are struggling to navigate the changing rules and are concerned about losing a significant portion of their customer base.

Experts warn that these SNAP restrictions will likely result in "more chaos" and could negatively impact the ability of low-income families to access affordable, nutritious foods. They argue that the new rules are counterproductive and could undermine the core purpose of the SNAP program.

Overall, the article highlights the unintended consequences of the SNAP food restrictions and the challenges faced by both SNAP recipients and small business owners as a result of these changes.

items.title: As carbon pipeline efforts stall, company eyes trucking the gas through North Dakota
items.description: Harvestone Low Carbon Partners is considering transporting CO2 from Dakota Spirit ethanol plant near Jamestown for underground storage.
items.summary:
Key Points:

1. Harvestone Low Carbon Partners is exploring trucking carbon dioxide emissions from its Dakota Spirit ethanol plant near Jamestown, North Dakota, about 160 miles west for underground storage.

2. The company requested a $20 million loan from North Dakota's Clean Sustainable Energy Authority (CSEA) in late January for its $95 million project, but the CSEA board voted against providing the funding.

3. Harvestone already operates a carbon storage facility at its Blue Flint ethanol plant near Underwood, North Dakota, where the CO2 has been pumped underground into the Broom Creek Formation since 2023.

4. Transporting CO2 by truck would not be a new practice, but the scale Harvestone is considering is. They plan to capture and store 230,000 metric tons of CO2 annually.

5. Building a pipeline to transport Dakota Spirit's emissions would be expensive, as a 160-mile pipeline would only move about 1,430 metric tons of CO2 per mile, compared to Summit's 2,500-mile pipeline which would move about 7,200 metric tons per mile.

6. Harvestone has an engineering, procurement and construction agreement with Minnesota-based McGough for the project, with a "guaranteed substantial complete" date in January 2027 and full commercial operations planned for later that year.

7. The potential for carbon storage in eastern North Dakota is limited due to the area's geology, so some form of transportation would be needed if companies want to capture, store or use industrial emissions from the region.

items.title: Improving waterhemp control by managing spray water pH
items.summary:
The study conducted in Rochester, Minnesota in 2025 evaluated how spray water pH adjustment and timing of spray solution mixing affected waterhemp control in a corn herbicide program. 

The treatments included a tank mix of atrazine and Acuron GT (at full or half rate) with NIS and AMS, with or without a pH-lowering and buffering adjuvant (AlpHa Shot), and mixed either six days prior to application or at the time of spraying.

Adding the pH-lowering adjuvant reduced spray water pH from 7.5 to 5.8, which improved waterhemp control by 10% at 24 days after treatment (DAT) and 7% at 112 DAT. Waterhemp density decreased by 64% and biomass was reduced by 55% in treatments with the pH adjuster.

The timing of mixing the pH adjuster (6 days ahead or at time of spraying) did not affect waterhemp control, density, or biomass. The improved weed control was observed at both full and half rates of Acuron GT.

The key takeaway is that conditioning the spray water to the proper pH can improve herbicide performance and season-long waterhemp management, regardless of when the solution is mixed. Testing water pH and using a water conditioner or buffering agent is recommended if waterhemp control has been inconsistent.

The study was conducted by Eric Yu and Ryan Miller, UMN Extension Crops Educators, and was published on February 17, 2026 in the UMN Crop News.

items.title: 5 Cover Crops You Can Plant in February
items.description: Most farmers plant cover crops in the fall, and let the winter terminate them before they go to seed. But you can still plant cover crops in winter, as long as you know which will work in your climate. Plant these five cover crops this month for early spring benefits. The post 5 Cover Crops You Can Plant in February appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
Requires soil temperature of at least 40¬∞F (4¬∞C).

Kale - A multipurpose cover crop that feeds the soil, farmer, customers, and livestock. Needs slightly warmer soil of at least 45¬∞F (7¬∞C). Certain varieties are specialty market items.

Daikon Radish - Also called forage radish, the long taproots reach deep into the soil to break up compaction and scavenge leftover nitrogen. Requires soil temperature of at least 65¬∞F (18¬∞C).

Oats - Grow quickly to prevent weed germination. Form beneficial relationships with fungi. Sow at a rate of 4-6 oz per 100 sq ft. Can be terminated without harvesting oats.

Buckwheat - A quick-maturing phosphorus scavenger that conditions poor soils. Attracts pollinators and beneficial insects. Can be used as an organic mulch.
